item.title: Virtual pet sim Weyrdlets is like Animal Crossing on your desktop, except you might get some real-life work done too
item.content:encoded:
https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/virtual-pet-sim-weyrdlets-is-like-animal-crossing-on-your-desktop-except-you-might-get-some-real-life-work-done-too

Procrastination bait meets productivity tools

When I was a kid, one of my absolute favourite things to do on the PC was to mess around with a free virtual Felix - like the cat from the cat food adverts - who would roam around the Windows XP desktop, chasing balls of string between program windows and curling up to take a nap on the taskbar. I have no idea where the game came from - a dream, perhaps - but 30 years later, I still think about it as a perfectly formed way to lose hours on the PC without actually doing anything.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

For that reason, a first glance at Weyrdlets initially had me worried. It’s more of a game than that virtual cat simulator, but scratches that same moreish itch of drifting into a zen-like state while watching a virtual pet just wander around and do its thing on your monitor screen. It seems like the kind of thing I could lose hours to without realising, looking up from the slightly clay-like animals’ idle digging for treasure to find night has turned to day or that it’s still 3pm, but the date has skipped forward.

Developers Weyrdworks seem to understand that there’s a dangerously distracting appeal to staring at colourful little oddballs just doing their thing, so they’re aiming to flip that power of procrastination into something a bit more productive. As well as being an Animal Crossing-style life sim you can casually mess with around whatever else you’re doing - with your pets able to use the treasure they collect to buy new clothes, snacks you can feed them and items to decorate their adorable island home with - Weyrdlets can also be used as a productivity tool, letting you set timers, create to-do lists and log a daily reflection in the company of your desktop pal using a set of handy widgets.

The life sim elements are all a lot less demanding than something like a Tamagotchi, though you’ll still need to chuck your pet a bit of food, give them some fuss and keep them active unless you can stand the guilt of seeing a sad little face hover on your screen. You can send off some encouragement in a bottled message to another player’s screen too, which is a cute Kind Words-like social touch.

It’s a neat mix of much-needed wholesome distraction and actual real-life utility that I can’t help but be drawn to - even if I know, deep down, that I’m far too much of a sucker for cute virtual critters to truly hone my focus on working while there’s a fun little lizard there to pet.

Weyrdlets has a demo on Steam now, if you’re curious to try it out yourself, with the full thing arriving on July 23rd.

item.title: Fallout 76 Gets Skyline Valley Map Expansion Today, Caravan Outposts in Fall 2024, Playable Ghouls (with Unique Perks) in Early 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/fallout-76-gets-skyline-valley-map-expansion-today-caravan-outposts-in-fall-2024-playable-ghouls-in-early-2025/

A few weeks ago, Bethesda Game Studios released the Skyline Valley Fallout 76 update on the public test server. Today, the studio is launching the patch (around 27GB on Steam) on live servers.

This is the first expansion to the open world map. Whereas previous new locations, such as Pittsburgh and Atlantic City, brought players elsewhere, Skyline Valley introduces a whole new area to the Appalachian map. More specifically, Bethesda has added the Shenandoah National Park area toward the south, below the Great Divide. Here, Fallout 76 players will find Vault 63, which is inhabited by non-feral ghouls.

The leader of Vault 63 is Hugo Stolz, who the developers described as having a 'particularly charged personality'. He's a friendly example of a new ghoul type called the Lost, who tend to be wary of outsiders. Throughout the new storyline, players will have the opportunity to either befriend or betray Stoltz. The new fearsome foe added with Skyline Valley is a trio of supersized robots called Storm Goliaths, developed by Vault 63.

There's also a hefty chunk of new quest content, twelve new quests to be exact, as much as the previous Steel Dawn and Steel Reign updates combined. There are new factions, new creatures, and new rewards. Lastly, a new public event called Dangerous Pastimes takes place in Skyline Valley. In this event, players take on the role of a storm chaser who needs to power up a big lighting rod to kickstart an electrical light show. The update kicks off Season 17 as well, which is themed around camp rewards.

Bethesda Game Studios also teased the next Fallout 76 update. Called Milepost Zero, it will be released this Fall, expanding Skyline Valley with brand new experiences. For example, the Blue Ridge Caravan Company has established a trade route on Skyline Drive and will need the adventurers' help to defend their Brahmin caravans. Funnily enough, the Brahmin can be slapped on the back to make them run a bit faster for a while.

Running missions for the Blue Ridge Caravan Company will eventually unlock a caravan outpost for the player character. Bethesda likened this to Skyrim houses in that the outpost can be decorated and host exclusive vendors. The Fall update will also add the Mischief Night Halloween-themed event, but the most exciting new feature might just be playable ghouls, which are coming to Fallout 76 in early 2025, likely on the heel of the excitement for Cooper Howard, the ghoul character played in the TV show by Walton Goggins.

Ghouls can be unlocked at level 50 when a quest will allow them to undergo the mutation process. Ghouls have unique benefits against radiation as well as 'dozens' of unique Perk cards to be used in addition to the existing Perks. The flip side is that the character's new appearance might not sit too well with some of the factions.

Lastly, Bethesda teased that the addition of Ghouls is linked to a new challenging endgame activity that will be detailed later this year. Following the 20 million player milestone, it's clear that support for Fallout 76 is here to stay.

item.title: Carian Study Hall walkthrough, how to solve the pedestal puzzle in Elden Ring
item.content:encoded:
https://www.polygon.com/elden-ring-guide-walkthrough/24174556/carian-study-hall-walkthrough-location-pedestal

The Carian Study Hall is a seemingly normal tower in the Liurnia region of Elden Ring. The tower is a stepping stone in Ranni’s questline, but its can be a little tricky as it turns out to be a messed-up funhouse home to a clown known as Preceptor Miriam.

Learn how to defeat Preceptor Miriam, use the pedestal to invert the tower, and get to the top in this walkthrough.

Carian Study Hall location

The Carian Study Hall is located on the eastern side of Liurnia and is just below the Artist’s Shack Grace. However, we do recommend that you cross the stone bridge behind the shack and descend the hill rather than taking a leap of faith off the cliff edge.

Before starting, we recommend that you progress through Ranni’s questline to the point where you’ve given Ranni the Fingerslayer Blade, after which she will give you the Carian Inverted Statue. In doing so, you’ll be able to explore the entirety of the Carian Study Hall in one go.

Enter the Carian Study Hall and head up either of the staircases. Move straight ahead to find an elevator, and ride it to the upper floor. Turn right to find a golden rune (3) on the corpse, where two spirits will spawn (you’ll be seeing a lot more of these).

Head up the stairs on the opposite side of the room to face off against Preceptor Miriam and her army of spirits. As you deal damage to Preceptor Miriam, they’ll teleport further and further up the tower. Continue to chase them until they teleport to the top floor of the tower. Before riding the elevator to the next floor, collect the Carian Glintstone Staff at the top of the stairs.

Ride the elevator to the top floor and go up the stairs, but don’t enter the next room immediately. If you’re using a ranged build, you can attack her from this room, simplifying the fight. For melee users, Preceptor Miriam will walk over to the room if you stay hidden in the corner beside the door.

When Miriam has gotten closer to you, you can jump out of the room and hopefully attack them to death. If they’re still alive and teleported away, we recommend climbing the ladder to the rafters above. From here, you can land a jump attack and take them out. After they’ve been defeated, you’ll receive the Magic Downpour sorcery spell.

Climb up the ladder to the rafters to find another ladder to the east. Go up to the top rafter and look southwest to spot a corpse with the Cerulean Seed Talisman. Return down the ladders and head to the eastern side of the floor to find a golden rune (4).

That completes the regular Carian Study Hall, so let’s return to the entrance for the inverted portion.

How to use the pedestal in Carian Study Hall

Before starting this section, make sure that you have the Carian Inverted Statue, which is given to you after you’ve given Ranni the Fingerslayer Blade as part of Ranni’s questline.

Teleport to the Study Hall Entrance Grace to find an altar with an interactable pedestal in front of a globe. Place the Carian Inverted Statue onto the pedestal to flip the tower upside down. Head up the stairs on either side and drop into the elevator shaft ahead, but make sure you land on the ledges!

Jump into the window and defeat the lesser fingercreepers inside. Ahead of you, you’ll see a large platform in the middle of the room with two lesser fingercreepers and (respawned!) Preceptor Miriam, who’ll sling spells at you from afar. Follow the path on your left and make sure to hug the wall before dropping onto the narrow ledge below. Turn around, collect the Mask of Confidence, and make your way to the middle platform to defeat Preceptor Miriam. Once slain, you’ll receive the Lucidity sorcery spell.

Facing away from the entrance, turn to the right and follow the path downwards, defeating enemies along the way. At the bottom of the path, look below you to find large circular chandeliers. Make your way down to the rafters below you by hopping from chandelier to chandelier.

Drop down to the lower rafters and collect two holyproof dried liver and eight glintstone fireflies off the nearby corpses. Hop down one last time to the hexagonal platform and step on the pedestal in the middle, which will technically ascend you to the top of the tower. Look to the east to spot large double doors that’ll take you to the Liurnia Tower Bridge Grace. The bridge will take you to the Divine Tower of Liurnia, but be careful as a Godskin Noble will spawn at the center of the bridge. After, you defeat the Godskin Noble, you’ll be able to progress in Ranni’s questline by ascending the Divine Tower and retrieving the Cursemark of Death.

item.title: Nokron, Eternal City walkthrough in Elden Ring
item.content:encoded:
https://www.polygon.com/elden-ring-guide-walkthrough/24174554/nokron-eternal-city-walkthrough-siofra-aqueducts-mimic-tear-ash-pillar-puzzle-location

Nokron, Eternal City, an area below the Liurnia region of Elden Ring, is home to a couple bosses (Regal Ancestor Spirit and Valiant Gargoyles) and a few quintessential items such as the Mimic Tear Ashes, larval tears, and the Fingerslayer blade. Nokron is also important to the Elden Ring lore, as the Ranni’s quest and Fia quest pass through the area.

Read on to find out how to find the Nokron entrance, make your way to the Siofra Aqueduct via the Regal Ancestor Spirit and Valiant Gargoyles, and how to get the Mimic Tear Ashes.

Nokron entrance location

To get into Nokron, you must first defeat Starscourge Radahn, a powerful boss located by Redmane Castle in Caelid. Once slain, Radahn’s control over the stars will wane, allowing a meteor to crash land in eastern Limgrave.

Approach the crash site, marked by a red icon on your map, from the northwest to find a path leading to the large crater.

Follow the path on the right and drop onto the rocks below until you spot an opening in the rock face. Continue through the entryway and make your way to the doorway below to enter Nokron, Eternal City.

As you enter Nokron, you’ll be greeted with a large cavern full of gothic architecture. Drop down onto the roof below and take notice of the square platform to the right. This can be a tricky jump, so brace yourself. Sprint along the thin rooftop and quickly jump to the right to land on the platform. Continue along the path where you’ll encounter another jump to a different building. Collect the loot off of the corpse here to receive the Ghostflame Torch.

Proceed to the eastern edge to spot three silver tears, a slime-like enemy, on the roof below. Defeat the silver tears and loot the corpses to find a rune arc. Continue down the rooftops to find another silver tear. Turn left to find two more silver tears and a corpse with 10 burred bolts.

Turn back to where you came from to spot the fallen building. Drop down to the building, defeat the silver tears, and collect the golden rune (6) and nascent butterflies off of the two corpses. Hop over to the adjacent building and progress forward to find an open window.

On the top floor, grab the smithing stone (5) and furlcalling finger remedy off of the bodies. Drop down to the next floor and turn around to find a golden rune (6). On the other side of the room, you’ll find a ghost glovewort (3). Head into the next room to find the Nokron, Eternal City Grace.

Mimic Tear Grace

Proceed out of the doorway, down the stairs, and into the open area with the gazebo. To progress deeper into Nokron, you’ll want to head down the stairs behind the gazebo, but before you do that, search the surrounding area for some key items. In the area around the gazebo, you’ll find the Ghost-Glovewort Picker’s Bell Bearing (1), a smithing stone (4), a smithing stone (5), ghost glovewort (3), and a ghost glovewort (4). In the building beside the stairs, defeat the two enemies inside and collect the larval tear. In the graveyards to the right of the stairs, you’ll find the Greatshield Solder Ashes and two ghost glovewort (3).

After you’ve received your items, head down the stairs and continue along the path to find a corpse with a golden rune (7)Ahead of you is a classic boss door that leads to the Mimic Tear.

The Mimic Tear will do exactly what its name says - mimic your character. It will equip whatever you have equipped when you enter the fog door. An easier way to defeat the Mimic Tear is to enter the area with nothing equipped and reequip all of your equipment after the boss spawns. Once defeated, you’ll receive two larval tears, the Silver Tear Mask, and the Mimic Tear Grace.

Regal Ancestor Spirit pillar locations

Go up the stairs and continue along the bridge to find a somber scarab, dropping a somber smithing stone (5), a golden rune (4), and a ghost glovewort (3). Cross the bridge until you reach an open area on your left.

In this region, six pillars need to be lit to unlock the Regal Ancestral Spirit boss.

As soon as you enter the area, you’ll spot the first and second pillars. Light these two pillars and hug the wall on your left to find the Ancestral Woods Grace.

Continue northwest along the wall and loot the somber smithing stone (5) off of the corpse in the shallow water.

Start heading north to find the third pillar beside a large stone column, but be wary as there is a lesser red wolf of Radagon lurking around the area.

Continue north to find a teardrop scarab that drops the Ash of War: Enchanted Shot. Proceed north to the cliffside for the fourth pillar, which is surrounded by giant rats.

Before you head to the next pillar, turn to the west to spot an overgrown ruin. Hop onto Torrent, jump over to the pillar ahead of you, and drop to the floor below to collect the ghost glovewort (5) and the golden rune (12).

Travel over to the northern wall and get onto the slanted wall. Make your way to the top, cross the platform, and hop onto the stone brazier before landing on the bridge. Inside the room, you’ll find an ancestral follower guarding a chest that contains an Ancestral Infant’s Head. There isn’t a conventional method of returning to the previous area, so instead you’ll need to teleport to the Mimic Tear Grace and cross the bridge again.

Instead of exiting the bridge at the initial point, continue until the end of the bridge to find the fifth pillar on your left. Pass the staircase with the lit pillars, and go southeast to find the fifth pillar surrounded by three ancestral followers. Continue southeast until you reach the initial bridge you crossed to light the sixth and final pillar.

In between the fifth and sixth pillars, you’ll find a staircase with six lit pillars leading to the Hallowhorn Grounds. At the opposite end, you can interact with the animal remains to encounter the Regal Ancestral Spirit boss, which, upon defeat, rewards you with 24,000 runes and the Remembrance of the Regal Ancestor.

Night’s Sacred Ground walkthrough

Teleport to the Ancestral Woods grace and jump over to the rooftop ahead. Continue to the edge of the rooftop and hop across to the ledge. Turn right and follow the ledge to where you’ll need to jump over to the building with a corpse that contains rejuvenating boluses. Turn the corner and head up the stairs to find a rune arc, and turn to the left to prepare yourself for yet another jump.

Jump across to the next building and follow the path to the right to find a celestial dew. Turn around and follow the ledge around the corner. Jump over to the next rooftop to collect the silver tear husk, and return to the original building with the stairs to grab another silver tear husk.

Hop onto the dome-shaped roof and then over to the next building to encounter two silver tears. Turn the corner and collect the silver tear husks and a golden rune (7) off of the corpses. Continue along the path, cross over the damaged walkway, and enter either of the two windows ahead. Drop into the building and head up the stairs to grab the Black Whetblade off the corpse. Hug the left wall to find an imp seal, which you’ll need a stonesword key to unlock. Defeat the Nox swordstress inside and collect the smithing stone (3) and the Mimic Tear Ashes from the chest.

Immediately after you exit the room, turn left and exit the left-most window. Jump across to the slanted rooftop and make your way through the open window on your right. Immediately inside, you’ll come across a corpse with the Nox Flowing Hammer. If you’re using a ranged build, feel free to take out the enemies below. If not, get ready to drop down, but be aware: the large silver sphere in the middle of the room is an enemy. After they’ve been slain, collect the larval tear from the silver sphere and exit the building through the large doorway.

Go to the Night’s Sacred Ground Grace on your left and rest if needed. Heading northeast, defeat the enemies and loot the corpses to receive a celestial dew and a golden rune (7). However, be warned that the last silver tear will turn into a troll. At the top of the stairs, enter the room beneath the enormous skeleton and open the chest to receive the Fingerslayer Blade and a great ghost glovewort. Take the waygate beside the entrance to return to the Ancestral Woods Grace.

Siofra Aqueduct walkthrough

Jump on your trusty steed, Torrent, and head northeast past the pillar and the jellyfish to the cliff’s edge. Before dropping onto the ledge, turn around to find a path leading to the top of the Hallowhorn Grounds. Head over to the corpse to collect the Mottled Necklace +1. Return to the cliff, jump down below, and move into the cave to unlock the Aqueduct-Facing Cliffs Grace.

Continue through the cave until it opens to reveal a tower-like structure. Jump from the cave to the slanted column, then drop into the building. A Lesser Crucible Knight will patrol between two of the buildings. Collect the Crucible Hornshield off the defeated Crucible knight, and cross the bridge leading to the southwestern building. Grab the Missionary’s Cookbook 5 from the corpse, and return to the initial structure.

Move northeast to spot another Lesser Crucible Knight on the edge of the aqueduct, and defeat this one to receive a somber smithing stone (6). Collect the smithing stone (5) off the corpse, and continue through the doorway nearby. Head down the stairs on your right and into the structure ahead to find a Tear Scarab that gives you the Order Healing incantation. On the outskirts of this structure, you’ll find a golden rune (13) and a golden rune (7) from two corpses.

Return to the location of the second Lesser Crucible Knight and head north to collect a golden rune (6). Turn into the room on your left, defeat the Fallen Hawk soldiers, and loot the rune arc inside. Go straight to the other side of the aqueduct to find an important NPC for Fia’s questline.

Up the stairs to the left of D’s twin brother (who is also named D), there is a fog wall that leads to the Valiant Gargoyles boss. Once defeated, you’ll receive 30,000 runes, Gargoyle’s Greatsword, and Gargoyle’s Twinblade. You’ll also unlock a method to travel to the Deeproot Depths through the coffin at the edge of the waterfall.

Now that you’ve explored the entirety of Nokron, the Eternal City, you’re ready to either dive into the Deeproot Depths to continue Fia’s questline, or now you have the Fingerslayer Blade, resuming Ranni’s quest.

Either way - get out there and see more of what the Lands Between has to offer.

Soon after Xbox’s big (and quite good) showcase on June 9, 2024, Starfield got a nice healthy update that finally delivered on the promise of quick and easy access to mods. While Starfield has had many mods on PC, it hasn’t been the most approachable for folks who aren’t used to installing mods manually or using custom-made mod launchers.

Read More: Shattered Space Looks Like The Dose Of Personality Starfield Needs

That got a whole lot easier with the Creation suite of mods, now available as a menu option directly in Starfield on both PC and Xbox. It’s early days for Starfield’s official mod support, but what’s on offer right now is a very promising direction for Bethesda’s big ‘ol space sim.

Mod load order, explained

If you’re new to modding, you’ll need to wrap your head around “load order,” which, as the name implies, is the order your mods load in.

Load order isn’t arbitrary. In fact, if you get the order wrong, you could break certain mods or the game entirely. There isn’t a perfect science to getting the right load order, either, but there are some general rules of thumb you can apply. Just be prepared to readjust your load order in case things go wrong.

Generally speaking, you’ll want to start your mod load order with any major patches, such as community-made patches. After that, you want to try and conceptualize which mods are likely to affect more of the game. Adding a new gun, for example, is a small addition, so that can go last. A mod that radically changes companion relationship mechanics, however, might be more substantial, as would something that affects weather or lighting.

Download the Creation Kit on Steam to make your own mods

If you’re up to the challenge of making mods yourself, be sure to check out the Starfield: Creation Kit on Steam. While creating your own mods is way outside the scope of this guide, this is the tool you’ll need if you want to get started making your own creations in Bethesda’s massive galaxy.

To change your load order, you’ll need to be in the Creations menu. Press Y (or T on keyboard) to look at your current mods and their order. LB (or X on keyboard) will let you change the load order. You can save or restore a load order configuration by pressing the view button or C on keyboard.

Read More: Starfield: The Kotaku Review

To check the load order while in-game (note: you can’t change load order while playing Starfield), head to the pause menu and select Creations. If you’re encountering issues with certain mods, this is the first thing to check. If you’ve got a lot of mods loaded into the game, it might even be worthwhile to have your phone or a pen and paper handy to jot notes down about what works or doesn’t work with certain mod orders and combinations.

Starfield’s Creation Mod categories, explained

When you launch into the Creation menu, you’ll see a Netflix-menu-like structure for mods. It’s not the most helpful sorting structure if I’m being honest and is a pain to navigate (especially on PC).

Fortunately there are some helpful mod categories which have some overlap. They are as follows:

Audio
Body
Cheats
Creatures
Dungeons
Environmental
Followers
Gameplay
Gear
Homes
Immersion
Misc
Outpost
Overhaul
Planets
Quests
Ships
Skins
UI
Visuals
World

These aren’t exclusive categories. And mods like Ainsymods’ “Better Dynamic Weather” will appear under Environmental, Gameplay, Immersion, and Visuals.

To sort by category, press Left ctrl on keyboard or left trigger on controller. From here you can choose among the different categories (as well as curated, featured lists of mods). You can also sort each of these alphabetically or by date of publication.

Unfortunately, you can’t sort by price. As you will have noticed, many mods in Starfield’s creation kit cost real money by way of a premium in-game currency you can purchase. This guide won’t wade into the debate over paid mods, but if you see a Fallout-esque lightning bolt symbol on a mod with a number, that means the mod costs real money.

Installing, changing, and managing mods

Modding any game, even ones with dedicated mod storefronts like Starfield, is a process of trial and error. Some mods will work, others won’t. Some will sound great on paper, but might not live up to your expectations.

To install a mod, you’ll need to add it to your library (you’ll see the option for this under each mod’s page). In the Load Order menu, you can tick and untick each mod to toggle whether or not it’s active. You can also disable a mod from its individual mod page if you have already downloaded and activated it.

When you start up a game after changing mods, you will get a prompt telling you that some mods changed. It will ask you whether or not you want to load with or without the mods you previously used. Also, some mods might require configuration within the game to work as expected. “Headshot kills any actor,” for example, will place an item in your inventory that opens a menu to configure its options.

While opinions may vary (and rightly so) on the quality of Starfield’s vanilla offering, the arrival of official mod support is sure to allow for vast and unexpected changes to Bethesda’s massive galaxy. I know I’m already feeling quite tempted to tweak the experience with a handful of mods and go for another deep dive myself.

The day is finally upon us! After many years of massive content updates, culminating in one of the best online experiences around, it’s time for Fallout 76 to expand further. This time, to the south! But what’s new in Fallout 76 Skyline Valley?

Every Added to Fallout 76 With Skyline Valley

The most significant addition to Fallout 76 to date is the map expansion, which includes Skyline Valley—the southern reaches of the map—in an area known as Shenandoah National Park. It includes new points of interest to explore, idyllic C.A.M.P. plots, and a brand-new vault, Vault 63!

The expanded map is definitely the highlight, of course, but that’s not all. Skyline Valley includes an additional Public Event, Dangerous Pastimes, and a unique boss type, Storm Goliaths.

What Does Fallout 76 Season 17 Include?

I truly cannot believe we’re already on Season 17 of Fallout 76. It doesn’t feel like that long, but here we are, toiling away in a brand-new zone, with unique challenges and rewards to unlock.

In this season, which features a Pioneer Scouts theme, we’ll enjoy four months of regular events, challenges, and updates, including:

  • Gold Rush
  • Double Mutations
  • Double Score
  • Double XP Weekends
  • Fasnacht
